items.content:
The sun is an ordinary yellow star, of which there are billions of others. Many stars you may see tonight are identical to the sun. They are just millions of times further away.

The sun is a huge sphere of gas held together by gravity. The interior of the sun (the core) is extremely hot. The sun radiates that energy on the outside (photosphere). With the amount of energy that the sun radiates in one second, we would have enough for 500,000 years to meet our energy needs on earth. Unfortunately, most of it disappears into space...

Corona
The stretched atmosphere around the sun is called the corona. During a solar eclipse, the corona is beautifully visible for a short time.

Solar Flares
A solar flare is an explosion on the surface of the sun. This explosion is caused by the sudden release of a large amount of energy.

Mantle
The part around the core is called the mantle. The mantle becomes less and less dense towards the outside and also less and less hot.

Photosphere
The visible exterior of the sun is called the photosphere. The photosphere is the layer where the light visible to us comes from.

Core
The inner part of the sun is called the core. The core has a diameter of 200,000 km. Here the temperature is the highest, over 15 million degrees.

Convection Zone
The convection zone is the region between the mantle and the photosphere. From this region, hot bubbles of gas rise toward the outer edge of the sun.

Earth is the third planet in our solar system from the Sun. The earth revolves around the sun in one year.

Life exists on Earth. To date, no other life has been discovered on other planets within our solar system or beyond.

The crust of the earth is about 40 km thick and consists of several plates.

Under the crust we find the mantle on which the plates float, so to speak. The mantle is about 2900 km thick.

Below the mantle is the core , divided into an outer core and an inner core. The core has a diameter of about 3470 km.

Onder de mantel zit de kern, verdeeld in een buitenkern en een binnenkern. De kern heeft een diameter van ongeveer 3470 km.

The atmosphere or atmosphere surrounds the earth .
The atmosphere is bound to the Earth by gravity .
Without an atmosphere, life is not possible on Earth.

The ozone layer is a layer in the atmosphere.
The ozone layer protects us from harmful UV rays.
UV radiation comes from the sun and can cause skin cancer.
The ozone layer is located at an altitude of about 30 km.

The equator is an imaginary line on the Earth's surface.
The line runs midway between the North Pole and the South Pole .
The equator divides the earth into a southern hemisphere and a northern hemisphere.

The imaginary lines on Earth that run parallel to the equators are called parallels or latitudes.

Meridians are imaginary lines on the Earth's surface that pass through both poles.
The prime meridian divides the earth into an eastern and western hemisphere.

If you want to indicate the position of a place on the earth, you use the latitude and longitude .
The latitude varies from 0° to 90° with the addition of N (north latitude in the northern hemisphere) or south latitude (southern latitude in the southern hemisphere).

The longitude varies from 0° to 180°, with the addition of OL ( East Longitude , east of the Prime Meridian, in the Eastern Hemisphere) or WL (West Longitude , west of the Prime Meridian, in the Western Hemisphere).

The intersection of the equator and the prime meridian has coordinates 0°, 0°.
On the image you can also see the point indicated with the coordinates: 40° N and 30° WL.
Het snijpunt van de evenaar en de nulmeridiaan heeft als coördinaten 0°, 0°.
Op de afbeelding zie je ook het punt aangegeven met de coördinaten: 40° NB en 30° WL.

heading.content: Earth around the sun - moon around the earth

items.content:
The Earth makes an almost circular orbit around the sun.
A circle around the sun takes 365 and a quarter days for the earth.
We call that a year .

Because we don't have quarter days, we introduced leap years .
Once every four years, the year gets one day longer: February 29.

The moon makes an elliptical orbit around the earth.
As a result, the moon is sometimes closer and sometimes further away.
This can be clearly seen in the two photos below.
On the right you can see the moon when it is close.
On the left is a picture of the moon taken with the same camera, but two weeks later.
Then the moon was at its farthest from the earth.

The earth revolves around the sun every year. The orbit of the earth around the sun is called the earth's orbit .

The Earth also rotates on its axis every 24 hours .
That is why there is day and night .
When it is light with us, it is night on the other side of the earth (e.g. in Australia).

The sun is highest at noon - at least in winter.
In the summer we introduced summer time : the clocks were moved forward one hour.
Due to summer time, it is light an hour longer in the evening in the summer.

In summer we have more hours of sun than in winter.

The fact that we have more hours of sun in the summer than in the winter is because the earth's axis is slightly tilted.
You can see this indicated in the image.

Countries in the Northern Hemisphere are in the sun for longer in the summer.
In the southern hemisphere it is the other way around.

The boundary between the Northern and Southern hemispheres is the equator .
Countries on the equator have the same number of hours of sun in summer and winter.
Why is it longer light in summer?

There are 24 different time zones on Earth.
A time zone is an area of ​​equal (standard) time.

The time in a time zone is compared to the time in time zone 0.
London is in time zone 0.

Amsterdam is in time zone +1.
In Amsterdam it is one hour later than in London.

New York is in time zone -5.
In New York it is 5 hours earlier than in London.

There are 8 different time zones in the United States.
In Russia there are 7.

China is the largest country with only one time zone: +8.

The moon revolves around the earth in about 28 days. When it is dark with us, we often see the moon. But the moon is just as often in the sky during the day, but it is less noticeable.

You speak of a full moon when the moon is facing us with the fully lit side. If you see half of the moon, you speak of a half moon. With a waxing moon, the moon is in the first quarter: the crescent moon is getting bigger.
After the full moon, the moon is in the last quarter and the moon is getting smaller and smaller; you speak of waning moon .

If the moon is lit from behind, you will not see the moon; you then speak of a new moon .
